intro: Hesperocyparis goveniana var. pygmaea, commonly known as the dwarf giant fir, is a small evergreen conifer native to the Pacific Northwest of the United States. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and short, stiff needles that are typically a deep green color. The plant produces small, spherical cones that mature to a reddish-brown color, and it is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas. It has a slow growth rate and is valued for its ornamental appeal in horticultural settings. This variety is closely related to other members of the cypress family and exhibits unique adaptations to its native environment.
